column2: The code unit should use cryptography signatures after serializing data

column2: The code unit should validate the integrity of serialized data before deserializing them

column2: The code unit should have restrictions on gadget chains before deserializing data
column3: The code unit reads serialized data
column5: When developers place no restrictions on "gadget chains," or series of instances and method invocations that can self-execute during the deserialization process (i.e., before the object is returned to the caller), it is sometimes possible for attackers to leverage them to perform unauthorized actions, like generating a shell.

column2: The code unit should populate a new instance when deserializing an object
column3: The code unit reads serialized data
column5: When deserializing data, populate a new object rather than just deserializing. The result is that the data flows through safe input validation and that the functions are safe.

column2: The code unit should not be deserialized

column5: Explicitly define a final object() to prevent deserialization.

column2: The code unit should not deserialize protected fields
column3: The code unit is deserializable and has fields that should not be deserialized
column5: Make fields transient to protect them from deserialization. An attempt to serialize and then deserialize a class containing transient fields will result in NULLs where the transient data should be. This is an excellent way to prevent time, environment-based, or sensitive variables from being carried over and used improperly.

column2: The code unit should avoid having unnecessary types or gadgets.
column3: The code unit is not meant to be deserialized
column5: Avoid having unnecessary types or gadgets available that can be leveraged for malicious ends. This limits the potential for unintended or unauthorized types and gadgets to be leveraged by the attacker.

column2: The code unit should deserialize only acceptable classes
column3: The code unit reads serialized data
column5: Add only acceptable classes to an allowlist. Note: new gadgets are constantly being discovered, so this alone is not a sufficient mitigation.

column2: The code unit should verify whether the serialized data have been replaced

column5: An attacker may be able to replace the intended file with a file that contains arbitrary malicious code which will be executed when the button is pressed.

column2: The code unit should accept only uploaded files whose content conforms to specifications

column2: The code unit should use denylists to validate uploaded files
column3: The code unit accepts the upload or transfer of a file
column5: Do not rely exclusively on looking for malicious or malformed inputs. This is likely to miss at least one undesirable input, especially if the code's environment changes. This can give attackers enough room to bypass the intended validation. However, denylists can be useful for detecting potential attacks or determining which inputs are so malformed that they should be rejected outright.

column2: The code unit should reject uploaded files with unintended extensions
column3: The code unit accepts the upload or transfer of a file
column5: For example, limiting filenames to alphanumeric characters can help to restrict the introduction of unintended file extensions.

column2: The code unit should accept uploaded files only with intended extensions
column3: The code unit accepts the upload or transfer of a file
column5: Define a very limited set of allowable extensions and only generate filenames that end in these extensions. Consider the possibility of XSS ( CWE-79) before allowing .html or .htm file types.

column2: The code unit should ensure the uploaded file has only one extension
column3: The code unit accepts the upload or transfer of a file
column5: Ensure that only one extension is used in the filename. Some web servers, including some versions of Apache, may process files based on inner extensions so that "filename.php.gif" is fed to the PHP interpreter.

column2: The code unit should perform case-insensitive evaluations of the extension of uploaded files
column3: The code unit accepts the upload or transfer of a file and the web server supports case-insensitive filenames
column5: When running on a web server that supports case-insensitive filenames, perform case-insensitive evaluations of the extensions that are provided.

column2: The code unit should validate both the content and metadata of uploaded files
column3: The code unit accepts the upload or transfer of a file
column5: Do not rely exclusively on sanity checks of file contents to ensure that the file is of the expected type and size. It may be possible for an attacker to hide code in some file segments that will still be executed by the server. For example, GIF images may contain a free-form comments field.

column2: The code unit should execute the uploaded file with the lowest necessary privileges
column3: The code unit accepts the upload or transfer of a file and execute it
column5: Run your code using the lowest privileges that are required to accomplish the necessary tasks

column2: The code unit should create isolated account with limited privileges when executing uploaded files
column3: The code unit accepts the upload or transfer of a file and execute it
column5: If possible, create isolated accounts with limited privileges that are only used for a single task. That way, a successful attack will not immediately give the attacker access to the rest of the software or its environment. For example, database applications rarely need to run as the database administrator, especially in day-to-day operations.

column2: The code unit should execute uploaded files in a sandbox enviroment (e.g., chroot jail)
column3: The code unit accepts the upload or transfer of a file and execute it
column5: Run the code in a "jail" or similar sandbox environment that enforces strict boundaries between the process and the operating system. This may effectively restrict which files can be accessed in a particular directory or which commands can be executed by the software.

column2: The code unit should not allow executing previously uploaded executable files with arbitrary input
column3: The code unit accepts the upload or transfer of a file
column5: The problem with the above code is that there is no check regarding type of file being uploaded. Assuming that pictures/ is available in the web document root, an attacker could upload a file with the name: (attack code) malicious.php Since this filename ends in ".php" it can be executed by the web server. In the contents of this uploaded file, the attacker could use: (attack code) Example Language: PHP <?php system($_GET['cmd']); ?> Once this file has been installed, the attacker can enter arbitrary commands to execute using a URL such as: (attack code) http://server.example.com/upload_dir/malicious.php?cmd=ls%20-l which runs the "ls -l" command - or any other type of command that the attacker wants to specify.

column2: The code unit should verify the type of files uploaded before executing them

column5: This code does not perform a check on the type of the file being uploaded ( CWE-434). This could allow an attack er to upload any executable file or other file with malicious code.

column2: The code unit should disallow path elements in uploaded file names
column3: The code unit accepts the upload or transfer of a file and store it in the local file system
column5: Additionally, the creation of the BufferedWriter object is subject to relative path trav ersal (CWE-23 ). Since the code does not check the filename that is provided in the header, an attacker can use "../" sequences to write to files outside of the intended directory. Depending on the executing environment, the attacker may be able to specify arbitrary files to write to, leading to a wide variety of consequences, from code execution, XSS ( CWE-79 ), or system crash.

column2: The code unit should not reuse a memory area that has been freed

column2: The code unit should not call a function via a pointer whose memory has been freed

column5: If malicious data is entered before chunk consolidation can take place, it may be possible to take advantage of a write-what-Confidentiality where primitive to execute arbitrary code. If the newly allocated data happens to hold a class, in C++ for example, various Availability function pointers may be scattered within the heap data. If one of these function pointers is overwritten with an address to valid shellcode, execution of arbitrary code can be achieved.

column2: The code unit should set a pointer to NULL once its memory has been freed

If custom authentication routines are required instead of those provided by the server, then these routines must be applied to every single page, since these pages could be requested directly.

column2: The code unit should require authentication when accessing cloud data

If access does not require authentication, it can be easier for attackers to access the data from anywhere on the Internet.

column2: The code unit should execute external commands that only created statically
column3: 1. The code unit executes external commands
column5: If possible, ensure that all external commands called from the program are statically created.

column2: The code unit should contain stringent allowlist that limit the character set to be used for validating filenames
column3: 1. The code unit accepts filenames or paths as inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module etc.)
column5: When validating filenames, use stringent allowlists that limit the character set to be used.

column2: The code unit should restrict the filename to have only a single "." character and exclude directory separators such as "/", if possible
column3:
1. The code unit accepts filenames or paths as inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module etc.)
2. It is feasible to restrict the directory separators such as "/" and characters such as "."
column5: If feasible, only allow a single "." character in the filename to av oid weaknesses such as CWE-23 , and exclude directory separators such as "/" to av oid CWE-36.

column2: Check if the code use a list of allowable file extensions
column3: 1. The code unit accepts filenames or paths as inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module etc.)
column5: Use a list of allow able file extensions, which will help to av oid CWE-434 .

column2: Check if the code duplicates the client side security checks on the server side.
column3: 1. The code unit handles client side and server side
column5: For any security checks that are performed on the client side, ensure that these checks are duplicated on the server side,

column2: The code unit should decode and canonicalize the input to the application's current internal representation before validating it.
column3: 1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
column5: Inputs should be decoded and canonicalized to the application's current internal representation before being v alidated

column2: The code unit should not decode the same input twice.
column3:
1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
2. The code unit accepts inputs that need to be decoded
column5: Make sure that the application does not decode the same input twice

column2: The code unit should use a built-in path canonicalization function to remove ".." sequences and symbolic links.
column3: 1. The code unit accepts filenames or paths as inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module etc.)
column5: Use a built-in path canonicalization function (such as realpath() in C) that produces the canonical version of the pathname, which effectively removes ".." sequences and symbolic links

column2: The code unit should use the lowest privileges to accomplish the necessary tasks
column3: 1. The code unit handles tasks with access control.
column5: Run your code using the lowest privileges that are required to accomplish the necessary tasks

column2: The code unit should create isolated accounts with limited privileges per task.
column3: 1. The code unit handles tasks with access control.
column5: If possible, create isolated accounts with limited privileges that are only used for a single task.

column2: The code unit should be run in "jail" or similar sandbox environment that enforces strict boundaries between the process and the operating system
column3: 1. The code unit accepts filenames or paths as inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module etc.)
column5: Run the code in a "jail" or similar sandbox environment that enforces strict boundaries between the process and the operating system.

column2: The code unit should store library, include, and utility files outside of the web document root or in a separate directory and ensure strict access control to the web server
column3:
1. The code handles web-based services
2. The code unit stores library, include or utility files
column5: Store library, include, and utility files outside of the web document root, if possible. Otherwise, store them in a separate directory and use the web server's access control capabilities to prevent attackers from directly requesting them.

column2: The code unit should restrict the information displayed in the error messages
column3: 1. The code unit displays error messages
column5: Ensure that error messages only contain minimal details that are useful to the intended audience and no one else. The messages need to strike the balance between being too cryptic (which can confuse users) or being too detailed (which may reveal more than intended). The messages should not reveal the methods that were used to determine the error.

column2: The code unit should accept unexpected values as inputs.
column3: The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
column5: An attacker could provide unexpected values and cause a program crash or excessive consumption of resources, such as memory and CPU.

column2: Check if the properties of input are correctly derived in the code unit
column3:
1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
2. The input properties are being used in the code
column5: Errors in deriving properties may be considered a contributing factor to improper input validation. (Context: properties include properties of raw data and meta data that include size, length, frequency, rate and so on.)

column2: The code unit should filter the input to remove dangerous inputs
column3: The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
column5: such as filtering ( CWE-790) - which attempts to remove dangerous inputs

column2: The code unit should encode and escape the input
column3: The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
column5: or encoding/escaping ( CWE-116 ), which attempts to ensure that the input is not misinterpreted when it is included in output to another component.

column2: The code unit should perform validation after combining data from multiple sources.
column3:
1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
2. The code unit combines data from multiple sources
column5: When your application combines data from multiple sources, perform the validation after the sources have been combined. The individual data elements may pass the validation step but violate the intended restrictions after they have been combined.

column2: The code unit should validate inputs when invoking code from another language
column3:
1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
2. The code unit invokes code from another language
column5: validate all input when invoking code that crosses language boundaries, such as from an interpreted language to native code. Consequence:This could create an unexpected interaction between the language boundaries

column2: The code unit should convert all inputs into the expected data type
column3: 1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
column5: Directly convert your input type into the expected data type, such as using a conversion function that translates a string into a number.

column2: The code unit should verify if the inputs value falls in the expected range of values after conversion.
column3: 1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
column5: After converting to the expected data type, ensure that the input's values fall within the expected range of allowable values and that multi-field consistencies are maintained

column2: The code unit should decode the input to the application's current internal representation before validating it.
column3:
1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
2. The code unit accepts inputs that need to be decoded
column5: Inputs should be decoded to the application's current internal representation before being v alidated (CWE-180 , CWE-181 ).

column2: The code unit should canonicalize the input to the application's current internal representation before validating it.
column3: 1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
column5: Input should be canonicalized to the application's current internal representation before being v alidated (CWE-180 , CWE-181 ).

column2: The code unit should perform repeated canonicalization until the input does not change.
column3: 1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
column5: Consider performing repeated canonicalization until your input does not change any more. Reason: This will avoid double-decoding and similar scenarios, but it might inadvertently modify inputs that are allowed to contain properly-encoded dangerous content

column2: The code unit should perform correct and consistent encoding at each interface while exchanging data between components
column3:
1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
2. The code unit exchanges data between different components
column5: Ensure that the proper encoding is applied at each interface.

column2: The code unit should explicitly set the required encoding whenever possible.
column3: 1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
column5: Explicitly set the encoding you are using whenever the protocol allows you to do so.

column2: The code unit should verify if the input tokens are in compliance with the rules of the specified or derived  types
column3:
1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
2. The code unit converts the inputs into tokens
column5: - compliance with rules for what is treated as a token specified or derived type

column2: The code unit should verify if the input conforms to the domain-specific rules
column3:
1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
2. A set of domain specific rules are provided
column5: conformance to domain-specific rules, e.g. business logic equivalence - ensuring that equivalent inputs are treated the same

column2: The code unit should verify the authenticity, ownership or other attestations about the input.
column3:
1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
2. Authenticity and ownership are relevant to the input
column5: authenticity, ownership, or other attestations about the input, e.g. a cryptographic signature to prove the source of the data Implied or derived properties of data must often be calculated or inferred by the code itself.

column2: The code unit should validate metadata (such as information about the raw data, such as headers or size)
column3:
1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
2. The code unit uses the metadata of the provided input
column5: metadata - information about the raw data, such as headers or size

column2: The code unit should validate the implied and derived quantities of the input data (such as such as the actual size of a file instead of a specified size indexes, offsets, or positions into more complex data structures symbolic keys or other elements into hash tables, associative arrays, etc.)
column3: 1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
column5: implied or derived quantities, such as the actual size of a file instead of a specified size indexes, offsets, or positions into more complex data structures symbolic keys or other elements into hash tables, associative arrays, etc.

column2: The code unit should validate the specified properties of the metadata (such as size, length, etc. )
column3:
1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
2. The code unit uses the metadata of the provided input
column5: Many properties of metadata may need to be validated upon entry into the code, such as: specified quantities such as size, length, frequency, price, rate, number of operations, time, etc.

column2: The code unit should validate the implied and derived quantities of the metadata (such as such as the actual size of a file instead of a specified size indexes, offsets, or positions into more complex data structures symbolic keys or other elements into hash tables, associative arrays, etc.)
column3:
1. The code unit accepts inputs from an external component (e.g., user, other module, etc.)
2. The code unit uses the metadata of the provided input
column5: implied or derived quantities, such as the actual size of a file instead of a specified size indexes, offsets, or positions into more complex data structures symbolic keys or other elements into hash tables, associative arrays, etc.
